p: There is a paucity of examples of ecosystem models linking marine environmental change and associated changes in primary productivity to krill and their predators in the Southern Hemisphere (Klein, Hill, Hinke, Phillips, & Watters, 2018; Tulloch et al., 2017). Earlier models have investigated the recovery of baleen whales from harvesting (Mori & Butterworth, 2006; Tulloch et al., 2017), and explored the role trends in krill populations may have in predator recovery (Klein et al., 2018; Plag√°nyi & Butterworth, 2012; Watters, Hill, Hinke, Matthews, & Reid, 2013). An integrated assessment of whale recovery under climate change is missing that links future recovery of individual whale species to multiple climate drivers and changing food availability (krill and copepods) across the Southern Hemisphere.
